properties.name: Te Ahi kā
properties.short-description: The Pou was a joint commission by Council and the Ngai Tahu MÄori Trust Board and created by master carver Riki Manuel.
properties.long-description: The Pou tells of Rakinui and PapatÅ«Änuku, celebrating the story of beginnings, that of MÄori and of more recent settlers, and is carved from a tÅtara log sourced from the Tai Poutini, the West Coast. The Pou also relates to the ancient pÄ site Puari. Puari was the name of an early Waitaha settlement which stretched from the banks of ÅŒtÄkaro Avon River at Victoria Square out to Bealey Avenue in the years between 1000 and 1500. The loop in the river that encompassed the site was an important mahinga kai (food gathering area). While little is known about this settlement or its occupants, many taonga (treasured possessions) have been found in this region. At its height the pÄ would have been home to about 800 Waitaha people.

properties.name: John Robert Godley statue
properties.short-description: This is a two metre bronze standing figure of John Robert Godley (1814-61), Resident Chief Agent for the Canterbury Association and the acknowledged â€˜Founder of Canterburyâ€™.Â
properties.long-description: Commissioned in honour of John Robert Godley (1814-1861) to commemorate him as the 'founding father of Canterbury', the statue was cast at Coalbrookdale village, England. There were claims that metal used for the artwork came from guns seized at Sebastopol during the Crimean war (1854-56). Before travelling to New Zealand the statue was exhibited at South Kensington Museum in London where contemporary critics were impressed by Woolner's portrayal of Godley. Woolner was a leading sculptor of the time and part of the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood, a movement advocating for a return to the realistic depiction of nature.

properties.name: Kate Sheppard National Memorial
properties.short-description: The Kate Sheppard National Memorial is a large cast bronze depiction of women in New Zealand, flagged by two bronze plaques inscribed with the history of the Womenâ€™s Suffrage movement in New Zealand, mounted on a upright ornate concrete plinth.
properties.long-description: Kate Sheppard (1848-1943) was an advocate for the equal rights of women and led a campaign to secure womenâ€™s right to vote which met with success in September of 1893. Unveiled at the centenary celebrations, a time capsule was placed within the monument recording sponsors, news and material depicting the lives of women of the day. The choice of Margriet Windhausen was controversial with some criticism that gender had been put ahead of merit. Windhasuen was born and studied Fine Arts in the Netherlands before moving to New Zealand in 1976

properties.name: The Chalice
properties.short-description: Chalice celebrates the new millennium and the 150th Anniversary of the founding of Christchurch and Canterbury by the Canterbury Association.
properties.long-description: Neil Dawson's magnificent Chalice sculpture is located in Christchurch's Cathedral Square. With a primary hexagonal steel structure and a solid steel conical base Chalice stands 18 metresÂ high, 2 metresÂ in diameter at ground level and 8.5 metresÂ in in diameter at the top, its shape designed to mirror the spire of Christchurch Cathedral. The metal is cut into shapes of native plants indigenous to the area. Artist Neil Dawson was born in Christchurch 1948, completed  Diploma of Fine Arts (Hons) at Canterbury University in 1970 and Graduated with a Diploma in Sculpture from the Victorian College of the Arts Melbourne in 1973. Dawson was awarded an Arts Laureate by the Arts Foundation of New Zealand in 2003.

properties.name: Coal Pile
properties.short-description: This 10-tonne pile of coal, cast in concrete, is about honouring the city's industrial history.
properties.long-description: It was commissioned by the Christchurch City Council in 2016 for the site of the former gasworks on the corner of Moorhouse Avenue and Waltham Road, opposite the Washington Skate Park. Mark Whyte

properties.name: Corgis on High
properties.short-description: Artist David Marshall sculpturedÂ the three life-sized corgis in 2003 to celebrate the 50th Jubilee of Queen Elizabeth II.
properties.long-description: One was stolen shortly after the February 2011 earthquakeÂ and the other two were removed and kept safe until they were re-installed in their High Street home in June 2014.

properties.name: Moai
properties.short-description: Moai is a stone sculpture by Rapa Nui (Easter Island) sculptor Tebo, and was unveiled in 2003.
properties.long-description: A gift to the city from Chilean Ambassador Carlos Appelgren Balbontin, the work marked 30 years of bilateral relations between Chile and New Zealand. Located at the Arts Centre.

properties.name: Nucleus
properties.short-description: Commissioned by the Art & Industry Biennial Trust and unveiled during SCAPE 2006 Biennial of Art in Public Space.
properties.long-description: For the artist, this 9 metre high artwork is a celebration of place. The simple singular form made of four equal parts is a reflection of Christchurch, with well-planned and laid-out built environment, where all the parts are connected and necessary for the whole to function. The plinth, with its exposed structure is a celebration of Christchurchâ€™s engineering and industrial heritage.

properties.name: Passing Time
properties.short-description: Passing Time is a twisting ribbon of randomly linked boxes - with each box depicting one of the years between 1906 and 2010.
properties.long-description: Passing Time is a twisting ribbon of randomly linked boxes - with each box depicting one of the years between 1906 (founding date of the Christchurch Technical College which became a technical institute in 1965 and a polytech in 1980) and 2010 (the date of the sculptureâ€™s production). The work can be walked around, walked through, touched and sat on. Auckland-based artist Anton Parsons is a graduate of Canterbury Universityâ€™s School of Fine Arts.

properties.name: Queen Victoria Statue
properties.short-description: Bronze statue of Queen Victoria mounted on large square stone base.
properties.long-description: The statue of Queen Victoria commemorates three important events in the history of Canterbury. It is a jubilee memorial to Queen Victoria (1881-1901). Relief work on the pedestal observe the fiftieth anniversary of the landing of settlers in Ohinehou Lyttelton in 1850. There are also reliefs to commemorate Canterbury's association with the Boer War, honouring those that died in service. The statue was incomplete when it was unveiled on May 25 1903, Queen Victoria's birthday. The bronze cast was produced by English sculptor Francis John Williamson. There were nine replicas of the statue, however, the Christchurch work has unique pedestal reliefs.  A few days after the statue was installed the cry of a cat was heard emanating inside. Before the being erected, the statue had laid on the ground where the cat had made its home. So Queen Victoria had to be hoisted off her pedestal while the cat was lured out.

properties.name: Rolleston Statue
properties.short-description: White marble statue on a stone plinth of William Rolleston, the fourth and last superintendent of Canterbury.
properties.long-description: The Rolleston statue was created by an English artist Herbert Hampton. Hampton was both a sculptor and a painter, and had been exhibiting at the Royal Academy since 1886. For the Rolleston commission Hampton created a marble statue in the â€˜Victorian frock and coat styleâ€™. Many of Rollestonâ€™s contemporaries found Hamptonâ€™s representation an accurate portrayal. The Lyttelton Times noted, â€œThe statue itself is a very good likeness. This was shown by the remarks made as soon as it was unveiled, many of those present saying that the likeness could not have been bettered.â€  William Rolleston was prominently involved in the politics and administration of the Canterbury province. His most distinguished public position was that of the fourth and last superintendent of Canterbury. The location of the statue on Rolleston Avenue between the Canterbury Museum and the original University buildings, now the Arts Centre is significant as Rolleston was the leading political impetus behind both these provincial institutions.

properties.name: Scott Statue
properties.short-description: Marble statue of Robert Falcon Scott set on stone base commemorating death of Scott and his party returning from the South Pole in 1912.
properties.long-description: Christchurch was the New Zealand base for British Antarctic expeditions led by Captain Robert Falcon Scott in 1901 and in 1910, with the South Pole reached on January 25, 1912. On the return journey a planned meeting with supporting dog teams from the base camp failed, although Scott had ordered his team to do so, and at a distance of 150 miles from their base camp and 11 miles from the next depot, Scott and his companions perished from a combination of exhaustion, starvation and extreme cold. Scott wrote â€œWe took risks, we knew we took them; things have come out against us, and therefore we have no cause for complaint, but bow to the will of Providence, determined still to do our best to the last ... Had we lived, I should have had a tale to tell of the hardihood, endurance, and courage of my companions which would have stirred the heart of every Englishman. These rough notes and our dead bodies must tell the taleâ€¦.â€ News of the death of Scott and his companions did not reach Christchurch until February 11, 1913.  A week after the news broke a committee was set up to organise a Scott memorial. Council entered into a contract with Lady Kathleen Scott (later Lady Kennet), a sculptor married to Captain Scott since 1908. A bronze statue was originally intended but when work began in 1915 all available metal was being used by armament makers with scarcity of material pushing the price up. Carrara marble became the viable alternative.  Scott portrayed her late husband in polar dress, facing north on the homeward journey. On the plinth the names of the expedition crew are inscribed along with an extract from Captain Scottâ€™s last note as he awaited death.  To avoid damage to the raised hand and leg of the sculpture, it was transported to New Zealand incomplete. Negotiations faltered over increased costs of completing the statue in marble, and Lady Scott did not travel to Christchurch before her death in 1947 so the statue remains unfinished.

properties.name: Taking Flight
properties.short-description: The Canterbury branch of the New Zealand Foundrymenâ€™s Institute donated this drinking fountain to the city with funding assistance from Christchurch businesses in 1993.
properties.long-description: Philip Price was commissioned to create the bronze sculpture which was cast at the Woolston foundry. Price designed the fountain to show a movement in time. The metal is fashioned in a light, flowing form, this gives the work the appearance of hovering. It is this captured movement that gives the fountain its name, Taking Flight. The location for the fountain in the woodlands area of South Hagley Park allows the fountain to draw water from its own artesian bore.

properties.name: Wrestlers
properties.short-description: Installed in 1990 in the Botanic Garden on the bank of the Ōtākaro Avon River, the art work shows two powerful bodies wrapped around each other.
properties.long-description: Over the years Llew Summersâ€™ sculptures have caused controversy and outrage. Wrestlers was no exception when it was bought by the Christchurch City Council. The controversy surrounding Wrestlers appears to have centred on concerns over the nudity of the figures.

properties.name: Solidarity grid Adelaide
properties.short-description: Mischa Kuball’s Solidarity Grid is based in the act of giving and the positive symbolism of light. A series of streetlamps  gifted to Christchurch from around the world located on Park Terrace between Armagh St and Bealey Ave.
properties.long-description: Solidarity Grid was commissioned by the Christchurch City Council and project produced by SCAPE Public Art. Over a period of three years, beginning with SCAPE 7 in 2013, streetlamps from 21 cities around the globe were gifted to Christchurch as a gesture of solidarity with the city during its recovery and rebuild process. These streetlamps have been installed along a section of Park Terrace, providing an actual as well as symbolic exploratory trail of light for pedestrians and cyclists.

properties.name: Trubute to Firefighters
properties.short-description: After the 9/11 disaster the city of New York gifted steel from the New York Trade Centre for the creation of this artwork. Graham Bennett’s tribute to firefighters honours and acknowledges firefighters worldwide. The sculpture is based on the angels created by Firefighters ladders.
properties.long-description: The artwork was commissioned by the Christchurch City Council and sited in the Firefighters Reserve at the corner of Kilmore and Madras streets. Christchurch was one of the few places around the world gifted steel from the World Trade Center.

properties.name: Taurapa
properties.short-description: A Christchurch and Seattle Sister City sculpture. Boulders are balanced against the uplifted sandstone slab, recognising that fragility and inviting destruction by man.
properties.long-description: The Seattle Sister Cities committee commissioned this artwork by Chris Booth. The brief for the work focused on Chief Seattle and his prophecy warning of the fragility of the cycles of nature. The Kai Tahu kaumatua Maurice Nutira helped locate the boulders for this project. Waka (canoe) once plied this river, and the form of the sculpture is reminiscent of the stern post of a waka. The land here is an alluvial deposit from the Southern Alps, from where these boulders came.

properties.name: An inside outlook
properties.short-description: By creating a monumental frame from heavily grained slabs of chlorite schist, Stuart Griffiths alludes to the deliberate construction of views within the Botanic Gardens.
properties.long-description: Approachable from either side, the sculpture frames two disctinct views and  heightens our awareness of an underlaying architectural scheme within a seemingly 'natural' setting.

properties.name: Cherubs
properties.short-description: A marble statuette of six cherubs, or putti, is enjoying themselves playing music and drinking.
properties.long-description: "This collection of statues is located in the Townend House in the Botanic Gardens. "

properties.name: E Noho Ra De Chiric
properties.short-description: E Noho Ra De Chirico was made by Paul Dibble for a 1995 exhibition and has two components: a leaf and a nude female torso.
properties.long-description: The sculpture was bought by the Robert McDougall Art Gallery for $30 000 in 1996. The two components of the sculpture were placed on either side of the entry to the Gallery. Plinths had been constructed on the sides of the entry to the Robert McDougall when it was built in 1932 and the Dibble sculptures were the first to make use of this design feature. Dibble’s intention for the work was to take the classical form of the European torso and to relocate it in a Pacific vernacular. Classical form is further alluded to in the title, E Noho Ra De Chirico which pays homage to De Chirico, a modernist who often placed classical elements within the modernist environment of his art.

properties.name: Eels
properties.short-description: Steel sculpture of three eels ontop of a steel hoop outside Parklands Community Library.
properties.long-description: Bing Dawe was commissioned to create a sculpture to “evoke the wetlands which existed across the Parklands area before European settlement, teeming with wildlife including native birds, fish and eels.”

properties.name: Engage
properties.short-description: A seven-piece work that stands four metres tall at its highest point and moves from outside the library to indoors.
properties.long-description: The curved metal blades (balanced with boulders from the Waimakariri River) are a reflection of the nearby meandering Heathcote River, the Port Hills behind and introduces a contrasting human element to the otherwise severe, straight lines of the library’s architecture.

properties.name: Fitzgerald Statue
properties.short-description: James Edward Fitzgerald was the first superintendent of Christchurch. Donated by Christchurch citizen Richard Green. The sculptor Francis Shurrock was a leading interwar New Zealand sculptor.  The Bronze statue is on a stone plinth on a concrete base.  A terrazo plaque is inscripted on the front of the plinth.  The inscription reads: 'James Edward Fitzgerald First superintendent of Canterbury 1853–1857.'
properties.long-description: "When Richard Green approached the Council about erecting a statue in Fitzgerald’s memory, initial response was favourable. Francis Shurrock a master of sculpture at the Canterbury School of Arts was commissioned to produce a sculpture for a site in Latimer Square. Problems soon surfaced with the relatives of Green. Green’s descendants instigated court proceedings, claiming that Green was neglecting the maintenance of his family. Claims were laid that Green was attempting to dispose of his money through the costs of the Fitzgerald statue. The Council received many strongly worded letters from Green’s relatives petitioning them to decline the statue. The Council’s response was to withdraw its acceptance until an outcome was reached with the court case. Under the instruction of Green, Shurrock had continued to work on the statue, finished the modelling and had it cast in England. However, when the statue arrived back in New Zealand, the dispute was no nearer conclusion so the statue sat in the customs yard for two years. Finally after prolonged negotiations it was agreed that the Domains Board would accept the Fitzgerald statue. In a brief ceremony the statue was unveiled on 3 February, 1939. Still the controversy over the Fitzgerald statue continued. The site that was chosen for the statue did not account for the modifications Shurrock had made for it to be viewed in the open space of Latimer Square. Instead the statue received a canopy of foliage. Further debate was aroused over the quality of stone that was used for the plinth. After the saga of the Fitzgerald statue the Christchurch City Council were wary of repeating the performance and it was some years before another public commission was undertaken.  "

properties.name: Flour power
properties.short-description: A SCAPE legacy work commissioned in conjunction with PAAG. Galvanised Steet light poles that look like sheafs of Wheat bound with a Car tyre.
properties.long-description: “….as if a friendly giant has walked through the garden city gathering lamp-posts like flowers and tying them into a bunch with a car tyre.” Regan Gentry

properties.name: Frank Arthur Worsley Bust
properties.short-description: Bronze bust on a tall concrete plinth.
properties.long-description: Frank Arthur Worsley (22 February 1872 – 1 February 1943) was a New Zealand sailor and explorer who served on Ernest Shackleton's Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition of 1914–1916, as captain of the Endurance. He also served in the Royal Navy Reserve during the First World War.

properties.name: Henry James Nicholas
properties.short-description: Memorial to Seargent Henry James Nicholas VC MM of the 1st battalion Canterbury Regiment who was killed in action on October 23, 1918 aged 26.
properties.long-description: Nicholas was awarded the Victoria Cross after leading an assult on a Greman stronghold in Belgium. The memorial was commissioned and gifted to the city in 2007 by the Returned Soldiers Association.

properties.name: Joy of Eternal Spring
properties.short-description: The work was installed early 2002 initally on loan and then a became permanent work in 2004.
properties.long-description: As part of the Charleston Neighbourhood Plan 193 Ensors Road was identifired as a potential location for art work. Lew Summers work was chosen for this site due to his connection to the area and the local High School (Linwood College).

properties.name: Moongazer
properties.short-description: Limestone carving of a carved figue gazing upwards into the sky.
properties.long-description: Llew Summers was born Christchurch, New Zealand in 1947.  He held his first exhibition in 1971 and since then has held many one-man shows as well as exhibiting alongside other artists including: Tony Fomison, Fatu Feu’u, Michael Smither, Tom Mutch, Peter Carson, Roger Hickin, Bing Dawe and Graham Bennett. He believes it is the role of the artist to challenge: “if it’s not challenging, then, in some way, it’s not new”.  His interest has been primarily in figurative works, and is celebratory of the human form, affirming the beauty of the human body.

properties.name: Pathways home
properties.short-description: Commissioned by Riccarton/Wigram Community Board and unveiled 18 June 2004. Gabion filled with river stones that were painted by the local community.
properties.long-description: The sculpture Pathways Home by artist Judith Streat will include 450 hand-painted stones in a design that “reflects the spirit of the Hornby community and the geographical nature of the area”. Funded by the Riccarton Wigram Community Board with sponsorship from Winstone Aggregates, Firth Industries, Steel and Tube, Resene Paints and Hornby Mall.

properties.name: Poppies over Gallipoli
properties.short-description: Features 6 tall red poppies that suspend the landscape of gallipoli.
properties.long-description: The sculpture was originally commissioned by the Burwood-Pegasus Community Board in 2003 and was designed by artists Ian Lamont and Judith Streat. The landscape has the words of Mustafa Kemal Atatürk engraved into it. Shingle from the beaches of Gallipoli and Canakkale has been gifted by the people of Turkey for use in the landscaping around the memorial.

properties.name: The Nature of Gothic
properties.short-description: Ruskin Street, Addington, was renamed in the 1880s and its statue and landscaped gardens were added in 2006.
properties.long-description: The sculpture is also linked to how the existing native plants made way for a new society of people, of people who planted a legacy of English and European trees, who created beautiful gardens, and who initially established the Anglican middleclass culture and values of Fendalton and made up the best of Christchurch society.”

properties.name: Serenade
properties.short-description: Judith Streat's chief inspiration for her sculpture, Serenade, was the story of WC Fendall and Lucy, which she describes, “The sculpture is about the elements that bind a community together, about courtship and enduring love.
properties.long-description: The sculpture is also linked to how the existing native plants made way for a new society of people, of people who planted a legacy of English and European trees, who created beautiful gardens, and who initially established the Anglican middleclass culture and values of Fendalton and made up the best of Christchurch society.”

properties.name: Sybil
properties.short-description: Five Steel sculptures that morph from cabbage trees to an angel.
properties.long-description: In the 1980s the City Council decided to rename some Addington streets after the famous literary figures of Victorian England, and to commission sculptures to be set in attractive green reserves in celebration of the writers and their works. Sculptor, Ian Lamont, chose to focus on the Benjamin Disraeli’s book Sybil, and the story behind the name, which comes from Greek mythology. Here a giant Sybil marshals a line of Lamont’s signature metal cabbage trees. Look closely and you will see her wings—another tie-in with Disraeli. Sybil is at one with the angels supporting the great man in pouring scorn on Darwin’s scientific challenge to Christian belief.

properties.name: The four winds
properties.short-description: Hewn from a block of Mount Somers limestone by Jenny Doyle. Four faces are carved on each side to represent the four winds.
properties.long-description: Donated by Jim Turner and the Waimari District Council.

properties.name: Under the eaves
properties.short-description: Features a bird filled nest of ivy and the intriguing quote from J M Barries' Peter Pan.
properties.long-description: In 2009 David was asked to create a sculpture in Barrie Street, in Addington Christchurch. The streets in the area are named for famous authors and have artworks themed to suit. His sculpture is mounted high on a lamp post, and features a bird filled nest of ivy and the intriguing quote from J M Barries' 'Peter Pan' on a scroll of metal, “Do you know," Peter asked, "why swallows build in the eaves of houses? It is to listen to the stories.”

properties.name: Untitled man with no name
properties.short-description: 3.5 meter corrugated Iron head and shoulders also known as the Beckenham Head. This was the first outdoor work in Christchurch of this artist.
properties.long-description: Made entirely out of corrugated iron, the sculpture is of the head and shoulders of a person and approximately 3.5metres high. In a bid to help boost interest in the shops and features in the area, the Spreydon/Heathcote Community Board gave $3500 to the Beckenham Business Association for the sculpture.

properties.name: Veracity
properties.short-description: Limestone sculpture by Kevin Butson based on a wooden sculpture in his collection.
properties.long-description: Limestone Sculpture commissioned by Suburban Estates as part of the Marblewood Subdivision. Based on a wooden carving in the collection of Kevin Butson. The original work was damaged by a car and the artist made some minor modifications to the work because of this.

properties.name: Addington Worker in Tune
properties.short-description: This Addington gateway work reflects the industrial history of Addington. It includes a railway track, Steel cut out of an Addington Brass player layered with another steel cutout of tools that would have been used in the Addington Railway Workshop.
properties.long-description: Commissioned by Spreydon/Heathcote Board as a gateway to addington the work is influenced by the history of the area, including the railway yard workshop and the Addington Brass a band which was established in 1883 as the Addington Workshops Brass Band.

properties.name: Tree Houses for Swamp Dwellers
properties.short-description: Incorporates light and plant forms and creates spaces within itself for reflection and play.
properties.long-description: Commissioned by Council and produced by SCAPE in 2003. Consisting of 10 modular objects that read and function both as trees and as houses the work can be engaged with and explored on many levels.

properties.name: Stay
properties.short-description: STAY comprises two identical works that translate a human body into a rising form of bold crystalline cells; both link time, place and consciousness.
properties.long-description: They look down: one into the moving waters of the Ōtākaro - Avon River and the other the paved ground of the Arts Centre. They are made of a concentrated earth material, iron. The works take a single moment of human time and place it in two distinct contexts: a tree-lined river where the trees were unscathed and the river never ceased to flow, and an historic building that, although damaged, survived the quake. Sited in the Northern Quadrangle the work is glimpsed laterally within the horizontal shelter of an imposed architectural order, whilst the other is immersed in nature. In these places the materialised memory of this particular body acts as measure and marker both in a humanly built habitat and the elemental world. STAY is non-monumental, at human scale; neither a landmark nor an icon, but a quiet catalyst for reflection. It is a form of acupuncture to revitalise a traumatised urban field. Each work marks a place, but will also talk to a time that does not yet exist. ” - Antony Gormley, July 2015

properties.name: Stay
properties.short-description: STAY comprises two identical works that translate a human body into a rising form of bold crystalline cells; both link time, place and consciousness.
properties.long-description: They look down: one into the moving waters of the Ōtākaro - Avon River and the other the paved ground of the Arts Centre. They are made of a concentrated earth material, iron. The works take a single moment of human time and place it in two distinct contexts: a tree-lined river where the trees were unscathed and the river never ceased to flow, and an historic building that, although damaged, survived the quake. Sited in the Northern Quadrangle the work is glimpsed laterally within the horizontal shelter of an imposed architectural order, whilst the other is immersed in nature. In these places the materialised memory of this particular body acts as measure and marker both in a humanly built habitat and the elemental world. STAY is non-monumental, at human scale; neither a landmark nor an icon, but a quiet catalyst for reflection. It is a form of acupuncture to revitalise a traumatised urban field. Each work marks a place, but will also talk to a time that does not yet exist. ” - Antony Gormley, July 2015

properties.name: Aquafluere
properties.short-description: The water featured in this sculpture by Phil Price is sourced from a diversion race that was hand-dug to redirect water from Wairarapa Stream to drive the mill.
properties.long-description: One of the earliest mills in Christchurch, opened in 1854 once stood 500m down stream from this sculpture.
